intro: Quercus calliprinos var. leptolepis, commonly known as the coast live oak, is a deciduous evergreen oak native to coastal regions of California and Baja California. It is characterized by its broad, leathery leaves that are typically 2–6 inches long and have a distinctive lobed shape. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for local wildlife. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to coastal climates with mild winters and warm, dry summers. Its ecological significance includes providing habitat and stabilizing coastal dunes.
